Award.AwardTitle: A Proposal to Provide Technical Assistance to Increase the Competitiveness of Minority-serving Institutions (MSIs) in the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The Quality Education for Minorities (QEM) Network will conduct a proposal development workshop aimed at increasing the development and awareness of grantsmanship opportunities related to the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program at Minority Serving Institutions (MSIs). The workshop will include two-person faculty teams from 20 MSIs interested in developing a competitive Noyce proposal. Participants will also engage in a series of post-workshop individualized sessions that will provide additional proposal guidance. The QEM workshop and post-workshop interactions will provide participants feedback on their required project summaries to assist them in developing their ideas into competitive Noyce proposals. MSIs are uniquely qualified to address the issue of recruiting, retaining, and developing STEM teachers for high-need schools. As such, the project's workshops will help develop stronger MSIs, in general, and teacher preparation programs, specifically, to meet the nation's needs for a more productive science and technology workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In July 2016, with NSF support, the Quality Education for Minorities (QEM) Network conducted a workshop to provide technical assistance to minority-serving institutions (MSIs) to increase their participation and competitiveness in NSF's Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program. The two-day workshop assisted two-person teams, from MSIs with accredited teacher education programs, in further developing their ideas for Noyce proposals for the FY2017 competition. Institutional teams, each consisting of a STEM faculty member and a teacher education faculty member, represented 20 MSIs in 10 states and the District of Columbia.

 

Workshop sessions included presentations by NSF Program Directors and QEM consultants. Key topics discussed included: overview of NSF and the Noyce program tracks; NSF’s merit review process and preparation of competitive proposals; project design, data management, assessment and evaluation plans; and project sustainability and institutional change. At the end of the workshop, participants completed evaluation questionnaires soliciting their feedback regarding their overall workshop experience. Thirty-seven of the 40 workshop participants responded to the questionnaire (93% response rate). Ninety-seven percent (97%) of them indicated that the workshop organization, clarity of goals, and overall experience was “excellent or very good.”

 

Following the workshop, teams were provided with additional guidance through QEM consultant-led post-workshop technical assistance activities. Four QEM consultants facilitated activities and provided feedback to teams. Eleven teams successfully participated in the sessions and the general consensus was that the assistance provided was beneficial to their proposal development and refinement. In particular, the quality and promptness of feedback provided were cited as key characteristics in strengthening their Noyce proposals. A review of the NSF/Noyce awards database by QEM staff following the 6-month proposal review period revealed that two of the institutional teams received awards in FY 2017 totaling over $1.7M.

 

The QEM Noyce project provided MSI faculty with hands-on training in the preparation and submission of competitive proposals to the NSF Noyce Program as well as professional development focused on current teacher education research and best practices. The materials on QEM’s Workshop E-resources file augmented the workshop’s training sessions. The skills training and professional development provided is transferrable to other academic pursuits as well as supports STEM faculty participation and leadership in education research and policy formation. Overall, project activities increased participants’ proposal development skills and awareness of Noyce teacher training tracks. The workshop provided a platform for faculty to network as well as discuss common issues and challenges with colleagues from other institutions.

 

The workshop agenda and links to presentations were posted on QEM’s website to facilitate sharing with a broader audience. Participants were strongly encouraged to share project information and materials with colleagues at their institutions. Data collected through follow-up surveys showed that teams shared materials with colleagues using the following avenues: 11 shared links to presentations on QEM website: 9 shared workshop packets: and 5 shared the E-resources file. A subsequent journal article, cited below, outlined the project features and impacts described above and explored development of a potential QEM technical assistance model for advancing teacher training programs.

Ivory A. Toldson, and Chance W. Lewis. “Advancing Teacher Training Programs at Historically Black Colleges and Universities through Technical Assistance and Federal Investments (Editor’s Commentary).” The Journal of Negro Education, vol. 86, no. 2, 2017, pp. 83–93. JSTOR, JSTOR, www.jstor.org/stable/10.7709/jnegroeducation.86.2.0083.

 

ABOUT QEM NETWORK

The Quality Education for Minorities (QEM) Network was established in 1990 as a non-profit organization in Washington, DC, dedicated to improving education for minorities throughout the nation. QEM works with minority and non-minority individuals, organizations, and institutions to help coordinate and energize efforts to improve the education of minorities, particularly in STEM.
